stories.title: Data centers écoresponsables: L’impact de l’hébergement des données

stories.text:
This is how it works:

1. Post your trial-project idea(s) that you would like to work on with your potential co-founder as a pilot project before committing to working on a startup.

2. Invite other members to join you, or join other member's trial-project.

3. Discuss each other's trial-project ideas and decide on one project that you would work together on a trial basis. Set a deadline for the project.

4. Demo your project to other members on the server.

5. Decide whether to work together on actual startup, or part ways.

6. If trial-project team clicks and decide to work together then congratulation; go build that next unicorn. Or go to step #1 above and repeat.

Server is at: https://discord.gg/qz6HcPKnbw
stories.title: I created a new discord server to find co-founders

stories.text:
I have a decade of experience developing .NET applications and would happily continue, but there are simply not enough relevant open positions in my city. Unfortunately my job applications are dismissed out-of-hand before even reaching telephone call.

I've completed coursera courses in different languages and referenced them in cover letters, but with no feedback I assume this makes absolutely no difference.

How did you manage to even get an interview for a position using a language/environment you're not familiar with? Am I unlucky having to deal with the stigma of "uncool" .NET?
stories.title: Ask HN: How did you transition to a new programming language?
